[{'document_title': 'TROUBLES IN CENTRAL AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Professor Bastian, of Berlin, has received the following letter from Dr. Fischer, the German African explorer, dated from Kagei: "The state of affairs at Uganda is very serious. The Arabs have lately been inciting the King against the Europeans, alleging that they purposed seizing the whole of Central Africa. Difficulties have also arisen with Unjoro, the Chief of that district having refused to receive any Europeans since his recent dispute with the Egyptians. Emin Bey is reported to have left Uganda, and there is consequently now no means of communication down the Nile. Mr. Mackay, the English missionary, is stated to have considerable influence over King Mwanga, who, however, has issued orders to all the neighbouring tribes not to allow any Europeans to pass through their territories unless coming from Uganda. King Mwanga's authority extends as far as Usakuma, and Englishmen, as well as Arabs, may do nothing in that district without his permission."', 'last_edit_date': '1886-03-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_03_1886#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.671, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African Times', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We have to record in our present number another sacrifice in the cause of Africa. The tidings of the murder of Bishop Hannington are too completely borne out to leave any room for hope that he managed to escape from the clutches of Mtesa's successor. King Mwanga seems to have had his suspicions aroused as to a possible annexation by one or other of the European Powers, and he came to consider the Bishop's entry into his territory as one of the steps in this direction. Many of our readers are aware that an obstacle to the opening up of Uganda has existed in the regular route from Zanzibar, for a vast extent of very unhealthy territory has to be traversed. Mr. Joseph Thomson's explorations revealed an alternative road, much shorter, and altogether more suitable for Europeans. In addition to its natural advantages, the new course possesses some of a political character, for German acquisitions threaten to block the line from Zanzibar to the Equatorial lakes. Bishop Hannington appreciated the importance of keeping the quick route open for missionary communication with the interior, and he resolved to be its pioneer. Within two days' journey of Rubaga, where the King of Uganda resides, Mr. Thomson had turned aside, seeing the full danger of proceeding further in that direction. This risk is owing to the dislike on the part of the King to intercourse by what correspondents call the "back door." Mwanga appreciates neither the utility nor the power of the Christian missionaries. He is in league with the Arab slave dealers, who hate missions in every shape, and he looked on the adoption of the direct route as an audacious invasion. Doubtless the fact that a portion of the road is through a country at war with Uganda intensified his wrath. The manner in which the King would be sure to view the Bishop's journey was so obvious that the latter...
Page 41', 'last_edit_date': '1886-03-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_03_1886#article-16', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.635, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Central African Mission', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The Uganda Mission has had and will have to encounter a force which is very restless and very powerful in Central Africa. In this region the Arab race, inactive elsewhere, retains something of its ancient vigour. For many generations it pervaded the recesses of the African continent, inaccessible to all other foreigners, for purposes of trade. European inroads upon its preserves in the present age have roused it and embittered it. Christian missionary efforts have provoked its theological emulation, which in Africa formerly was an aspect it was not especially solicitous to display. The result is a fury in the resistance to Christian civilization seldom exhibited of old. Arab opponents of the missionaries have an argument always ready which is sure of reception in the native mind. They denounce the strangers as "land-eaters," and the negro is prepared to believe the charge. Undoubtedly Europeans, particularly Englishmen, have been and still are "land-eaters," but they can with a good conscience repudiate any inclination of the sort towards Central Africa. The difficulty is to convince a negro, who regards his country with loving admiration, that the C.M.S. is inspired by no lower motive than compassion. Suliman's insinuations of the covetous intentions of Mr. Mackay's compatriots find an echo in the breast of Mwanga, which only the experience of time can still. The possibility of the choice of the route by Uganda for the Emin expedition is known to have alarmed the King. He feels that, if an occasion be wanted for proceedings against him, his butchery of Bishop Hannington has furnished it. The situation, with all its risks and perplexities, is pictured in Bishop Parker's letter. Evidently it demands the employment of the highest gifts of patience, sympathy, and diplomacy. Many persons in the security of their own country may be disposed to be indignant at the use of forbearance towards a guilty wretch like Mwanga. They would be glad to chastise him and his councillors. If the effort be too costly, the alternative, in their view, is to leave the people to its savagery. Force, if it were otherwise practicable, would be utterly wasted. The sole chance for negro vitality is the cultivation of a sense of national self-respect among the natives and the offer of Western civilization as a support, not as a solvent, of territorial independence. The existence of the Mission, lying altogether in Mwanga's power, yet staying against his declared will, is more conclusive evidence of the strength of Christianity in Africa than would be its predominance by the tyrant's dethronement. There would have been no shame had the Mission voluntarily broken itself up in the face of the young King's insolent enmity. Its persistency is magnanimous; it is the one way of testing the ability of Christian truth and humanity to hold its ground without the accessories of gunboats and rifles both against heathendom and Islam.', 'last_edit_date': '1887-11-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1887#article-12', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.655, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Voyage of the Raleigh', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'There has lately been published an account, from the pen of one of its victims, of the late revolution in Uganda. The Rev. Mr. Gordon was among the missionaries stationed at Uganda, and was expelled with the others when the second stage of the revolution had resulted in the power passing into the hands of the Arabs. After a period of imprisonment, he and his companions were placed in a boat upon the Victoria Nyanza, and bidden to depart, as it had been determined that no white teachers should live in Uganda. The value of Mr. Gordon's account consists principally in the picture it gives of life and politics in Uganda, and the light it throws on the designs of the Arabs in Central and Eastern Africa. Mwanga, the son of Mtesa, had his father's cruelty without the latter's strength and statecraft. During his life Mtesa had encouraged strangers, both Christians and Mohammedans. Hence arose two sects of reformers, Christian and Mohammedan. Mwanga trusted neither, but employed both. His misgovernment exasperated all; while he was plotting to destroy both parties. But they suspected his design, and joining together, succeeded in deposing him. For a short time

[MARCH 4, 1889.

all went well; "peace, quietness, and justice began to reign in the land," we are told; but soon discussions arose, the Arab traders saw that the growth of Christian influence was fatal to the slave trade, and they began to intrigue against the Christian ministers of the new King Kiwewa, who, they got him to believe, were plotting against him—the idea being that the Christians wished to be governed by a woman, as in England. The chief of the Christian party managed also to offend the King, and this became the signal for the outbreak of a fresh revolution. The Mohammedans attacked the Christians—who were obliged to flee for their lives, two of the chief among the latter being killed. The Mohammedans, supported by the Arabs, were now in the ascendant, new officers of state were appointed, and the missionaries—both French and English—were cast into prison, being after a few days released, and told to leave the country, with the injunction: "Let no white man come to Buganda for two years. We do not want to see a white teacher back in Buganda till we have converted the whole people to the Mohammedan faith."', 'last_edit_date': '1889-03-04', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_03_1889#article-10', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.654, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'DR. PETERS IN AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'On January 13 he proceeded, crossing Masai countries of Kamasia and Elgiyo, fighting his way through both, then on through the plains of AngataNanyuki, arriving on January 30 at Kavirondo. There he fell in with about fifty men of Jackson’s expedition, who had been left in charge of the camp while Jackson and the remainder of his force had gone north to shoot elephants. Jackson had arrived at Kavirondo in October 1889, but hesitated about advancing into Uganda, thinking his party not strong enough to assist the Christian party against the Arab faction then in possession of Uganda, King Mwanga having offered to accept the British protectorate if assisted by Jackson.

Peters stayed four days at Kavirondo, and while there assisted the Sultan to fight a hostile tribe called Mangati, living on the north-east coast of the Victoria Nyanza. These he beat, and then hoisted the German flag there. After this he turned to the north-west, towards Emin Pasha’s most eastern station, which he hoped to reach. Up to this time Peters had received no news of any sort.

Early in February he reached Kwateleessa, and thence proceeded as far as the Wachores country, or Akola, about six days’ journey from Emin’s first station. Here he received news from the Uganda natives that Emin had gone away with Stanley. He asked these people about the position of the Christian party in Uganda, and learned that they were taking refuge in the islands in Lake Victoria Nyanza, as they had possession of all the boats, and when unable to resist the Arab faction retreated to the islands, where the Arabs could not follow them.

Peters then marched slowly west towards the Nile, hoping news would overtake him. At this time a letter from Stanley addressed to the English expedition, which Stanley expected would be then at Ussoga, fell into Peters’s hands, and as they had not arrived Peters opened it, and thus got the news he wanted. He then marched south-west to Uganda, and on the way received invitations from the Christians to come and assist them. At Ussoga, Peters, on February 16, slept in the place in which Bishop Hannington was murdered. On February 17 he crossed the Nile at Ripon Falls, and marched into Uganda, the country being all waste through the frequent fighting of the rival parties. As he approached, the Arabs fell back on Unyoro, and on February 24, when he reached Kissallo Sallo, four miles north of the King’s residence, the King and the Europeans who were in refuge with him came on with Peters to the residence and took possession again. King Mwanga then solemnly declared he was free from any engagement with the English, and Peters made him sign the Congo Act and grant free trade with, passage through, and liberty of residence in his country to all Europeans, regardless of any distinction of nationality, and further made him sign a declaration forbidding the slave-trade in his dominions or the export of slaves out of his country.', 'last_edit_date': '1890-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1890#article-1', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.638, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Captain Lugard on the State of Uganda', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'On Nov. 30 Captain Lugard delivered an address to the members of the Liverpool Chamber of Commerce on the possibilities of Uganda as a field for commercial enterprise.

Captain Lugard said that on his arrival in Uganda he found the country so torn by internal dissensions that almost his whole time was taken up with administration. Hence the commercial value of the districts concerned had not as yet been fairly tested or received adequate attention. The source from which he had hoped to raise a revenue in Uganda was mainly by dues on ivory and by certain taxes. Traders from the coast would pay a trading tax on their exports to assist the cost of administration, and there would, of course, be no monopoly of trade. The only dues levied would be such as were due in recognition of the advantages enjoyed. A poll tax on natives he looked upon as a dangerous experiment. The products of interior Africa were of two classes—those whose value rendered them profitable under present modes of transport, and those which would be available with cheaper transport. Of the first class the most important was ivory. It was his idea at one time that the supply of ivory must rapidly fail; but he had come away from East Africa with the knowledge that there were yet vast quantities of ivory available, but elephants were being destroyed wholesale by the Manyema hunters and the Arabs of the Congo Free State. Unless concerted action were taken for their preservation it would be a Quixotic humanity to stand by to see the Manyema fill their pockets at our expense. But measures should be taken for the preservation of elephants in districts of the British sphere. Next in order of value for export purposes was coffee. There was plenty of room in Uganda for the cultivation of coffee and even of cereals. In the Southern Soudan large quantities of cotton were grown, and its culture was being introduced in the areas adjoining the Albert Lake.', 'last_edit_date': '1893-01-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_01_1893#article-0', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.669, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'BRITISH EAST AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Meantime it is said that the Company contemplates the abandonment of Uganda, and leaving it to the French Catholic missionaries. It is to be hoped that this statement is exaggerated. The functions of General Mathews are very different from those of Mr. Johnston in Nyassaland and Major MacDonald in the Oil Rivers. He has no administrative control, his duties being more of a consular character. His residence will be near Kilimanjaro, though probably he will be often on the move. Still, his appointment implies responsibility on the part of the Government for the promotion of British interests in this part of Africa; and this is not consistent with a passive attitude.

The news that Dr. Peters contemplates the subjugation of the Masai around Kilimanjaro is serious. The result will be to drive these Masai north into British territory, and probably to rouse their fellow-tribesmen there. The Company will be able to cope with any general Masai rising, but the drain on its resources would be trying.

The disaster to the German expedition is at a spot too remote directly to affect British interests. This disaster is a serious one for the Germans, and will no doubt be followed by a strong expedition to enforce vengeance. Fortunately nothing of the kind has been deemed necessary in the British sphere.

It will be of interest to give some information concerning the recent expedition of Captain F. D. Lugard from Mombasa to Uganda. It shows clearly what is the actual condition of things in the Company's territories, and to what deplorable condition Uganda has been reduced.

The expedition was carried out during the latter half of 1890, and the report was written in Uganda at various dates up to February 1891. Captain Lugard went over much the same route as he himself and Mr. Jackson did on previous journeys from Mombasa to Melindi and along the Sabaki river, and advocates that this should be the route for the railway. It seems to have more in its favour than any other. Much of the country is barren, but there are many valleys covered capable of agricultural development. Captain Lugard makes many recommendations as to what might be done which no doubt will have serious attention. Elephants, camels, and mules may all be used as beasts of burden. Captain Lugard received orders to proceed at once to Uganda—the state of affairs was most critical—and lost no time in carrying out his orders. He did his best to get together a force, but all included, he had only 300 men and a Maxim gun, but its ammunition was scanty. He felt he must make as speedy a march as possible, and take the Waganda by surprise; and so proceeded through Kamasia and Upper Kavirondo to Usogo, the country which borders on Uganda. He met with no obstacles of importance. The country passed through is 5,000 ft. to 8,000 ft. above sea level, clothed with vegetation of meadows and hillsides of England. Under settled administration much could be made of it.", 'last_edit_date': '1891-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1891#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.665, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Captain Lugard on the State of Uganda', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'After speaking of the production of gums and cereals in Uganda and adjoining districts, Captain Lugard said that culture of cereals for export must depend on cheap transport. The interests involved in holding the key to Central Africa and the Nile sources were sufficient to warrant the authorities in constructing a railway. He had suggested that it should be constructed at least half way, so as to cross the zone in which the fly fatal to transport animals was found. This would give access to fertile areas, reduce the cost of transport more than half, and relieve the Uganda budget of the expense of the connecting stations from the coast to the Lake. If the railway realised their anticipations it could be carried on for the remaining section to Lake Victoria, the best objective point in Africa. The whole question of the civilisation and development of these countries would then be solved, and new fields opened up for commercial activity. Then the Victoria would not be the sole objective of the railway; it would be the centre towards which the trade of all these countries would radiate. He pictured in the future an extension from the Victoria Lake through Budda to the Albert Edward Lake. He pictured in the more remote future further extensions along the plateau at the foot of Ruwenzori to the Albert Lake, and southwards to the north of Tanganyika; and thus the great system of the Lakes of Central Africa would be connected, and the slave trade would receive its death-blow. From the south of Tanganyika to the waters of the Nile, from Gondokoro to Mombassa by rail and steamer, we should control the country and civilise and develop it. If the railway to Kikuyu proved successful, its extension to the Lake was a matter of course. From the Victoria to the Albert Edward was only 140 miles, and from there to the Albert some', 'last_edit_date': '1893-01-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_01_1893#article-0', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.634, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'EASTERN AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'An interesting letter from the Rev. Dr. Krapf, dated Kornthal, 6th ult., was reported lately to the Committee of the Church Missionary Society, relating the results of his recent visit to the scene of his former missionary labours on the East African Coast. The Wanika tribes appear to be more promising than in former years. "We might have employed," writes Dr. Krapf, "hundreds and thousands of Wanika in manual labour, for they came from all quarters, even from the neighbouring tribes, in quest of work. I was quite astonished at the industrial habits which the Wanika have adopted since 1859, when I left their country. The loss of their cattle by the marauding Masai, as well as the successive famines which they have sustained during two or three years past, seem to have effected this beneficial change. Now, they do not ask for 'presents,' but for manual labour; now, European teachers are welcomed whenever they may wish to reside among the Wanika tribes.', 'last_edit_date': '1863-02-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_02_1863#article-21', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.638, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The People of Lagos upon European Influence upon the West Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"Looking at the question from an economist's point of view, commercial intercourse with foreigners enriches our country. It enables us to import those commodities for the production of which the climate and soil of foreign countries are best calculated, and to export in payment those articles for which our own situation is better adapted. It is virtually a mode of cheapening production, the commodities exported rising in value, and those imported decreasing in value, caused by the increase of demand in the one, and of supply in the other. At the same time, the manufacture of those commodities for which we have no particular facilities is decreased. Take cloth, for instance; the manufacture of cloth out here costs at least a fifth more than if imported. West Africa has great natural advantages for the cultivation of the palm tree; thus the manufacture of palm oil is carried on with great success. This commodity is enough not only to supply the wants of the people, but to satisfy the demands of England, Germany, and other European countries, which, owing to climate, are unsuited for the cultivation of the palm. Thus, from an economist's point of view, commercial enterprise of Europeans in Africa is good for three reasons. First, it enables us to profit by the inventions and discoveries of the Europeans, from whom we get steamers, canals, railways, and the minor advantages of art and science, and also a certain amount of refinement in dress and manners. Then, being dependent on each other for a large amount of comfort and enjoyment, it forms a powerful principle of union, and binds the society of nations together by the common and powerful ties of mutual interest and reciprocal obligation. And, lastly, by bringing us into competition with foreigners, the division of labour is carried to its farthest extent; it stimulates our industry, and forces routine to give way to invention. Commerce is the principal medium for the propagation of Christianity. In some West African countries, Europeans are at first only admitted for commercial purposes. Up the Niger and at Bonny, for instance, persecution of converts to Christianity, especially by slave-holders, was of common occurrence; but this has been greatly modified by the interposition of the European merchants. When making treaties with native tribes, the Consuls usually stipulate for religious toleration. Again, missionaries have to avail themselves of commercial conveniences such as steamers, and also of commercial protection and aid; how would the money for missionary enterprise be forthcoming but for commerce? What is religion but an exalted form of civilization? The Bible contains as good a code for the improvement of mind and manners as any book extant.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-02-16', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1885#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.667, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE FUTURE OF UGANDA', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Speaking of the British East Africa Company's method of Government in his report, Sir Gerald Portal says: The history of British East Africa for the last five years and its present condition show us clearly that the experiment here of combining administration and trade in the same hands has proved a failure, and that the sooner this system is discontinued the better it will be for the Native races, for British commerce, for Zanzibar, and, I believe, for the Company itself. He holds that the work of the British East Africa Company might now be looked upon as ended; and there would be little difficulty in obtaining the withdrawal, or resignation of the Charter granted them by her Majesty, and suggests that the Company in surrendering concessions received from Zanzibar would be entitled to compensation from the Sultan. Sir Gerald recommends that an English Commissioner be appointed for Uganda and the neighbouring countries as far as the eastern border of Kavirondo, with a staff of 13 English officers and a force of 500 Soudanese soldiers. The duty of the British Commissioner would be to ensure the safety of Europeans living in Uganda, to repel foreign enemies, to prevent and suppress civil war and rebellion, to collect Customs duties, encourage commerce, and repress slavery and the slave trade. He recommends a road commandant to be appointed, to have control of the transport service from Kikuyu to the Lake, to effect all possible improvements in the means of communication, to exercise supervision over Arab, Swahili, and European caravans. He should with this object be given certain magisterial powers. His force should consist of one European assistant and 167 porters at an estimated cost of £4,750 per annum. A station or depot should be established at the head of "Berkeley Bay," chosen last year by the railway survey as the site for a suitable harbour at the north-east corner of Lake Victoria. This should be the farthest open for caravans. Communication thence to Uganda should be by water. Two small steam launches or cutters should be sent up of a speed of not less than five miles per hour and adapted for burning wood. Each should be under the charge of an English engineer. By carrying or towing the goods of traders these boats should earn the expenses of their maintenance. A Commissioner should be appointed to reside at Kikuyu with a staff of four Europeans, sixty Zanzibar soldiers, and 239 porters, &c. The establishment of this station, with stores of food and a colony of cultivators around it, would go far to diminish both the expense and the difficulties of the journey to the Lake. The total cost of this establishment would be £6,600 per annum. The road from the coast to Kikuyu might, if no better solution could be adopted, be left in the hands of the Zanzibar Government. So long as the present system of transport is maintained along what is called the English route it would be necessary to make greater provision for the safety and independence of the local authorities. Under existing conditions not only would any real progress be laborious and uncertain, but the retention of authority in Uganda and any improvement in the condition of that country would react mainly to the benefit not of ourselves, but of the German colony. Transport from the German coast to the south shore lake is cheaper, the road is more frequented, porters are more easily obtained, and food is more abundant than in the English sphere. Arab and European traders from the south, by their ivory and slaves in Uganda, avoid payment of any kind of duty to British authority by taking their caravans to the German coast ports. In Uganda there exists a demand for European commodities such as cotton cloths, boots, and clothing. If the present system of transport is continued these articles will be supplied from German sources and by the German route. To stop this system the transport by the English route must be made the safest, cheapest, and quickest. It would then drain the commerce of all the countries lying around Lake Victoria. Sir Richard Burton affirms that "Mohammedans alone make proselytes in Africa." Dr. Blyden, a full-blooded Christian negro, recently the Liberian Minister at the Court of St. James, is an unexceptional witness. In his recent work entitled "Christianity, Islam, and the Negro Race," he says that in Western Africa "Mohammedanism is rapidly superseding Paganism. In this way, silently and unobtrusively, they are causing princes to become obedient disciples and zealous propagators of Islam." These Moslem missionaries go from town to town and village to village, simply as the bearers of God's truth. They take their mats or their skins and their manuscripts, and are followed by their pupils, who in every new Pagan town form the nucleus of a school and congregation. These preachers are the receivers, not the dispensers, of charity. In the interior missionaries are to be met from Kairwan, Cairo, Morocco, dependent for their food upon those whom they instructed. As to the results of this noiseless propaganda of these devoted men, Professor Blyden tell us that "between Sierra Leone and Egypt the Mohammedans are the only great intellectual, moral, and commercial power. . . . Islam has taken possession of and shaped the social, political, and religious life of the most intelligent tribes. . . . hh: Missionary activities in Africa during the colonial period were deeply intertwined with colonial interests, serving as cultural intermediaries, influencing territorial negotiations, and shaping local societies through religious, cultural, and political dynamics.
result: The observations from both the "General History of Africa" textbook and The African Times news articles provide substantial support for the claim that missionary activities in Africa during the colonial period were deeply intertwined with colonial interests. The textbook highlights how missionaries acted as agents for European colonialism, consciously paving the way for European intervention and serving as cultural intermediaries. They were instrumental in establishing colonies for freed slaves, which weakened local societies and facilitated colonial rule. Missionaries also played a role in spreading Western education, closely linked to evangelization and supported by colonial administrations, and their presence often opened the way for colonial claims during the partition period. Similarly, The African Times articles emphasize the role of missionaries as cultural intermediaries, such as Rev. Alfred Saker in the Cameroons, who spread Christianity and introduced elements of civilized life, including reducing local languages to written forms and translating religious texts. The articles depict missionaries as influential in shaping local societies, with their work often linked to broader colonial goals like suppressing the slave trade and promoting legitimate commerce. They also mention missionaries' involvement in territorial negotiations, such as arbitrating between tribes in the Yoruba territory, aligning with colonial interests in maintaining peace for trade. Both sources discuss the collaboration between missionary societies and colonial administrations, indicating a shared interest in the civilizing mission. However, The African Times also highlights tensions, such as the negative impact of European traders on missionary efforts and criticism of missionary conduct, complicating the narrative of missionaries as purely benevolent actors. Overall, both sources provide a nuanced view that aligns with the claim, illustrating the complex interplay between missionary activities and colonial interests in Africa, influencing territorial negotiations and shaping local societies through religious, cultural, and political dynamics.

These included the creation of chancelleries to be managed by literate Africans to control diplomatic relations with Europeans and guide the external relations of the states; the reform of tax systems by the introduction of regulated taxes in place of tolls and tribute; and the improvement of the judicial system by the introduction of record-keeping and putting enacted laws into writing. 15", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.713, 'probability_score': 0.049, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Colonialism in Africa: its impact and significance', 'section_title': 'The colonial impact > The impact in the social field', 'content': 'The spread of Christianity, Islam and western education was another important impact of colonialism. There is no doubt that taking advantage of the peace and order as well as the patronage and in some areas the positive encouragement provided by colonialism, Christian missionaries and Muslim clerics pushed their activities further and further inland. As K. Asare Opoku has shown (Chapter 20), Christianity and Islam gained far more ground during the colonial period than had been the case during the previous three or four centuries put together. Islam also spread rapidly in West and East Africa as a result of the general improvement of communications during the colonial period and the patronage of both the French and the British rulers. In all the colonies, the mother tongue of the colonial power, either in its pure or pidgin form, became the official and business language and in many cases the main means of communication between the numerous linguistic groups that constitute the population of each colony. Education and evangelization were so closely linked that for many parts of Africa the pitching of the missionary tent was synonymous with the establishment of a school. Among the Nguni the opening of a school is said to have preceded the opening of a church in all cases. 4
The colonial administrations, on their part, hoped through the school to raise the low-grade personnel they needed for staffing the bottom echelons of the colonial bureaucracy, to create such conditions - political, economic, social and moral - as would enable Europe to exploit as fully as possible what were regarded as the hitherto insufficiently tapped resources of Africa. They created conditions for the truly displaced African in the most literal sense of the word. The Arabic dimension was unique in its own right, an ambivalent face of expansionism which none the less left strong cultural impressions on the landscape. Yet the reality that we extract from that period is the resilience and even increased vitality of the forms and values of the authentic cultures of the peoples.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.751, 'probability_score': 0.051, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The social repercussions of colonial rule: the new social structures', 'section_title': 'Change and continuity', 'content': 'Nor is the 'traditional-modern' polar model, with all its attendant implications of conflict and incompatibility, applicable to the entire spectrum of African experience of change under colonialism. There were manifold variations in the reaction of African cultures to western innova› tions. Not only were certain customs and beliefs discarded or modified, but some were retained at one level of society at the same time as new alternatives were being accepted at another level. Thus while human sacrifice, the slave trade and the killing of twins were discarded in societies where such practices had existed, and old and new ideas were amalgamated in the sphere of religion, the European ideal of monogamous marriage, accepted as part of an expected public image by sections of the westernized elite, exists side by side under the law with the institution of polygamy among the urban and rural masses. Today we have existing side by side in Africa indigenous and European architectural traditions; local ethnicity and nationalism; local and regional-locked economies and a notional money economy; rural and urban life; western bureaucratic institutions and traditional local authorities; Ku'ranic and Western schools.
Thus with ease many indigenous African institutions and ideas survived the impact of, or even blended with, alien European values. There is, for instance, the case of the Igbo who are often regarded as having massively embraced western ways. They see no contradiction, and have no difficulty, in combining Christian and traditional Nguni rites in marriage and funeral ceremonies.$^{2}$ Professor Fallers has also described some Ugandan groups as 'enthusiastically and successfully' accepting many elements of modernization - confining their influence, and adapting them to traditional culture and social structure. Abubakar has recently pointed out and as is evident from many of the chapters above, most of the African states were acquired as a result of the conquest and deposition or exile of the then rulers which 'certainly brought into disrepute the whole business of chieftaincy, especially during the period before the First World War'.$^{13}$ Some of the colonial powers, such as the French as we have seen already, also abolished some of the traditional monarchies and ruling families altogether, appointed people as chiefs who had no right to such posts and turned all of them into admini› strative officers. Betts has shown (Chapter 13), created some where they did not exist and tried to administer the colonies through them. [{'id': 100, 'article_title': 'Sherboro', 'full_section_title': 'Sherboro', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_02_1863#article-7', 'issue_date': '23_02_1863', 'content': 'As we are firmly convinced that the Sherboro River will become the channel of a large cotton trade, the state of the countries on its banks, and adjacent to it, becomes a matter of increased importance. We stated in our last that a ton weight of cotton in seed had been sent down by one of the chiefs as a sample. This indigenous cotton is very good, much resembling New Orleans. But we are glad to find that a considerable quantity of Sea Island seed has also been imported from America, and is being gratuitously distributed to those who will undertake to sow and cultivate it.

But war and bloodshed, kidnapping and slavedealing, are so antagonistic with cotton-planting, or any other productive agricultural industry, that the pacification of the Sherboro countries is indispensable to their industrial prosperity. We are glad therefore to find that the moral influence of the British Government—the great peacemaker in native Africa—is being exercised with some effect in districts that have been long the theatre of violence, plunder, and bloodshed. The following account, furnished by our friends the American missionaries there, contains several particulars that we are sure will be read with great interest and satisfaction, while all must deplore the enormous and guilty waste of industrial resources which these incessant native wars involve. But the final paragraphs may well cause us great pain. It is deplorable to see that persons, most of whom have been themselves delivered from slavery by the philanthropic efforts of Great Britain, in its crusade against the horrible slave-trade, should, after having enjoyed the advantages of British protection and education, become accomplices for gain in the atrocious work of kidnapping and slavedealing. We do indeed hope that severe punishment will fall upon such evildoers, who bring reproach upon Africans, and great discouragement to those who are striving for the elevation of their race.

**State of the Sherboro.**—The general aspect of affairs in the Sherboro is more peaceful than a month since. The agent appointed by the Government to negotiate a treaty of peace between the parties of the "Kittam war" met a number of the chiefs of the Boom at Barmana, who consented to his visiting the Galinas, and gave a pledge that no war should be made in the Kittam while he was there. He found the Kittam country entirely depopulated, and the towns destroyed. It is said that in the recent expedition to the Kittam, 461 captives were taken by the Bompey chiefs, and from 100 to 200 prisoners...'}, {'id': 277, 'article_title': '1863 AND 1864, AND THE AFRICAN-AID SOCIETY.', 'full_section_title': '1863 AND 1864, AND THE AFRICAN-AID SOCIETY.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_12_1863#article-14', 'issue_date': '23_12_1863', 'content': "Years interlace, and 1863 can only be adequately estimated in conjunction with 1864, as so many of the strenuous efforts made throughout 1863 can only then be realised. If, as we hope, some life be infused, during 1864, into that almost defunct colony of the River Gambia—if Sierra Leone, and its present good administration, extends its influence, and makes that influence more effective for pacification, security, agricultural development, the advancement of industry and commerce—if the Government take advantage of circumstances on the Gold Coast to open up communications, and to fix the British power firmly on the frontiers of Ashantee—if Quittah be reoccupied and the slave-trade be there extinguished, and if slave export be prevented between that place and Whydah, only fifty miles of seacoast—if there be no human sacrifices at Abomey or Kanna during Consul Burton's official visit to the King—if Dahomey appears for the first time as a cotton exporter—if reasonable councils, which will foster instead of destroy trade, prevail at Lagos—if the great River Niger be systematically navigated and traded in, as the commencement of permanent uninterrupted commercial operations with the great interior of Africa into which it leads—if the shores of Ambas Bay, at the foot of the Cameroons Mountain, show a settlement under secular as well as missionary enterprise—and if the River Congo cease to export slaves for Cuba and be opened to legitimate commerce—Africa will have made at least a good step in 1863 and 1864 toward progressive civilization; **and to all this the African-Aid Society will have powerfully contributed."}, {'id': 340, 'article_title': 'CAPE COAST.', 'full_section_title': 'CAPE COAST.', 'last_edit_date': '04-11-1864', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1864#article-5', 'issue_date': '23_05_1864', 'content': 'Still, when the road is constructed, only half the work is done! Who will repair the road? Shall a society of missionaries do it? We have done it for several years, because the Government would not undertake it. But this is wrong: it is both impolitic and unjust.—Yours truly,  
C. L.

**CAMEROONS.**

As the Rev. Alfred Saker is temporarily absent from the Cameroons for the recovery of health, we cannot refrain from giving our meed of praise to this Baptist missionary for his long and arduous labours there. He has planted on a barbarous coast, and amidst a most savage people, a Christian colony, whence civilization and the Gospel may spread. He has taught them some of the arts of civilised life; has reduced their language to a written form; has translated and printed the whole New Testament and portions of the Old, as well as prepared a vocabulary, a grammar, and several primary school-books. The Rev. Alfred Saker is the gentleman who formed for native Protestant refugees from the persecutions of Fernando Po, when that island was restored to the Roman Catholic Spanish authorities, the steadily progressing settlement of Victoria, on the shores of Ambas Bay.

**NEW CALABAR.**

In our March number we gave an account of the destruction by fire of a number of English trading vessels at New Calabar by fire. By accounts which have just reached us, having been delayed en route, we learn that the matting with which the ships were "armed" had been rendered so dry, by the "Harmattan winds," that it caught fire on board the ship which was first in flames from a mere spark that escaped from the cooking-house on deck. This vessel had above 1,000 quarter barrels of gunpowder on board, and its explosion was terrific. All the other ships in the river were, of course, in an equally inflammable state from the "Harmattan winds;" the concussion started many of their timbers; six of these ships then caught fire from the explosion of the first, and one of these having some 1,500 quarter barrels on board, shortly after exploded also. Altogether seven vessels were entirely destroyed, and one other was damaged. Three, the property, as before stated, of Messrs. Horsfall, of Liverpool, and of the Company of African Merchants, alone escaped. We are glad not to hear of any loss of life; and have no doubt that in future such precaution will be taken as will render any similar catastrophe impossible.

**LAGOS.**

TO THE EDITOR OF THE AFRICAN TIMES.

Sir,—Recruiting is being carried on here successfully for the 5th West India Regiment.

One of the great obstacles Government has to contend with at Cape Coast is the frequent removals of officials because of illness. D. A. C. General Thompson, in charge of the Commissariat, and Acting Stipendiary Magistrate and Queen’s Advocate, in all which he seems to have given great satisfaction, has been unhappily invalided home, after only two months’ residence.

This is only one of many instances.

The Peace Ambassadors from the King of Ashantee have not yet made their re-appearance at Cape Coast.

The Governor-General, Major Blackall, has visited the Governments of Cape Coast and Lagos, and returned to Sierra Leone.

The trading intercourse between Lagos and Abeokuta had not yet been restored; but efforts at an amicable settlement of the differences between the two Governments were making by English missionaries from Abeokuta who had arrived at Lagos for that purpose.

THE AFRICAN-AID SOCIETY has in vain endeavoured to procure an extension of the monthly postal service of the African Royal Mail steamers to Loando. Her Majesty’s Treasury, most unwisely parsimonious in this instance, refuse the necessary grant of money, though the outlay would be compensated for by savings at the Admiralty, independently of the national benefits to be derived from increased trade between Great Britain and the Portuguese possessions. The Spanish Ministry have laid before the Cortes a project of law for suppressing the slave-trade, the provisions of which, however, by no means respond to the exigencies of the case, although more stringent and severe than those of any law heretofore enacted in Spain for putting an end to that atrocious blot on the Christian civilization of the nineteenth century.'}, {'id': 3102, 'article_title': 'ARRIVAL OF BISHOP STEERE AT ZANZIBAR, AND HIS PROGRESS IN THE INTERIOR OF AFRICA.', 'full_section_title': 'ARRIVAL OF BISHOP STEERE AT ZANZIBAR, AND HIS PROGRESS IN THE INTERIOR OF AFRICA.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1876#article-19', 'issue_date': '01_05_1876', 'content': 'Bishop Steere and his party arrived at Zanzibar on February 10. **PROGRESS OF THE UNIVERSITIES’ MISSION TO CENTRAL AFRICA.**'}, {'id': 4425, 'article_title': 'Native Character in West Africa', 'full_section_title': 'Native Character in West Africa', 'last_edit_date': '12-29-1881', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1882#article-5', 'issue_date': '01_05_1882', 'content': 'We extract the following interesting letter from the American **Spirit of Missions**, as it gives a good insight into native character and prejudices:—'}, {'id': 4861, 'article_title': 'Consecration of a Bishop for Eastern Africa', 'full_section_title': 'Consecration of a Bishop for Eastern Africa', 'last_edit_date': '07-01-1884', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_07_1884#article-4', 'issue_date': '01_07_1884', 'content': 'On the 24th ult., being St. John Baptist's Day, at Lambeth Church, adjoining Lambeth Palace, the ceremony of consecrating the Rev. There was a large congregation. The sermon was preached by the Bishop of Saskatchewan, from Luke ii. 8—"Receive ye the word of God;" and in the course of it he described the characteristics of the fields of labour to which the Bishop as designate was to be sent, and said the East African (Nyanza) Mission was largely due to the liberality of the Church Missionary Society. The new Bishop will be essentially a missionary, and has, before this, had considerable experience in that capacity. The foundation of this see comes appropriately at a time when Sir Bartle Frere's death has reminded us of all that great man has in past years done for missions. It is, indeed, the consummation of a work suggested by him. It was under his advice that the Church Missionary Society started its important station of Frere Town; and no man would rejoice more heartily in the progress marked by Bishop Hannington's consecration had he but lived to see the day.'}, {'id': 5358, 'article_title': 'The Murder of Bishop Hannington', 'full_section_title': 'The Murder of Bishop Hannington', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1886#article-11', 'issue_date': '01_04_1886', 'content': "The Rev. The Bishop's caravan, after leaving Rabai on the 22nd of July, moved on steadily to Kavirondo without encountering disaster, except at Ngongo, where it was detained for some days, seeking food. **Jan. 1, 1887.**
