Mr. Farler cannot be blamed for carrying the war into Dr. Lenz's own territory. Travellers are the favourites of the period; and in no career are the prizes more abundant and brilliant. All the world admires the traveller. The missionary, whom few admire, and certainly not the general public, may think it hard that a casual visitor, whom probably he has aided and befriended, should be listened to as if he were Her Majesty's Inspector of Schools when he informs Europe that African missionaries are worthy people who do a great deal of harm. An Englishman who exiles himself to Central Africa enjoys few of the compensations within the reach of the African traveller. He suffers a hundredfold the privations, and he has to wrestle with a barbarism which may be perverted into something worse by undigested education and proselytism. It would not have been surprising had an African missionary, who has resigned the advantages of civilization and attractive prospects in his own land, infused some bitterness into his retort to a rather too magisterial condemnation of his whole object in life. But the real question remains, whether the charge be true, whoever brings it. The opinion of most who examine the evidence will probably be that any large _dictum_ to the purport that missionary work in Central Africa is all illusory is a gross exaggeration. From unimpeachable testimony it is clear that missionary settlements in the country are bearing fruit, whether much or little. Negroes are actually redeemed from debasing sensuality, superstition, and indolence. There are missionary villages in Central Africa which would compare favourably with many English hamlets. The picture Mr. Farler draws of his own station is corroborated by a body of independent testimony, and it demonstrates the accomplishment of marvellous results in a dozen years. Attention there is fully paid to the primary duty of teaching the native the virtue of regular industry, which he had unlearnt through the excessive complaisance of nature. So long as the effort is sustained there can be little doubt that the beneficial effects will go on, and that the individuals subjected to this process will lapse no oftener than professing Christians in Europe and America.\n\nThere seems to be no ground for questioning the soundness of the influence of British Protestant Missions, so far as its scope extends. The cause of this stagnation or decline, so contrary to what ought to be, is very easy of comprehension. The quantity of produce brought down from the interior depends entirely upon the purchasing and carrying capabilities of the monopolizing native traders at the oil ports. These purchasing and carrying capabilities are not increasing, nor is there any probability that they will increase under the institutions that now prevail. Bonny has made some little progress in civilization and Christianity: the king and some of the chiefs, or their sons, have received, more or less, education in the missionary schools of Sierra Leone and in England, but there seems good reason to doubt whether that education has developed in them those principles which alone can tend to raise the moral, social, and commercial reputation of their town and country. It is with reluctance and sorrow that we feel compelled to make this statement, because we had hoped for far better results. The missionaries of the Church Missionary Society, under the impulse and inspection of Bishop Crowther, are, we hope, progressing, but they are not a little impeded by the heathen prejudices, practices, and interference of some of the principal chiefs. At Calabar the Scotch Presbyterian missionaries have laboured zealously for many years, and with some effect; but, alas! how little compared with what might have been hoped from such devoted labours. The same may be said of the Cameroons River, where the Baptist missionaries have worked with ardent devotion for five-and-thirty years. They have given education to many, and made, we hope and believe, many sincere individual converts; but they have not obtained a dependable ameliorating influence as regards the abominable heathen customs and institutions of the country. The colony they have founded at Victoria, Ambas Bay (in the immediate neighbourhood of the Cameroons River, at the foot of the mountain), with their converts expelled from Fernando Po by the Spanish authorities, is, however, a bright spot of promise, from which a most salutary influence may yet spread to the interior. And this is all we have to record as the fruit of five-and-thirty years, effort by ardent Christian societies in England, and devoted labourers sent out by them to those countries south of Lagos. We say nothing of the River Niger, because there we have an opening to the interior. Our business just now is with the said Oil Rivers only; and we repeat, that the condition and prospects of civilization, Christianity, and commerce are the very reverse of satisfactory or encouraging, and this is the more afflicting, in view of the vigorous efforts making in so many other directions for removing the dark veil of ignorance and superstition with the paralyzing influences inseparable from heathenism. Our notice has been called to this matter of the Oil Rivers by letters from Old Calabar, which appeared in our June and September numbers, and again by some words in the account of the exploration journey from the Cameroons which we now publish. The letter in our June number seems to show that the heathen despots of Old Calabar have grown daring by impunity, and in defiance of the treaty regulations with Great Britain, are doing their utmost to extirpate the Christianity that has been planted among them. The writer sums up by saying: "The persecution of the poor is grievous; there are no laws—nothing but arbitrary and arrogant dealings. The whole country is full of robbery. In consideration of the cruel treatment of Christians, and slaves who desired to become Christians, and who are crying for help, we think that Calabar ought to become an entry port." To become an entry port, means to be placed under British jurisdiction. Mr. Greenfell, the Cameroons explorer, says, "The head men in the river are anxious to be under Her Majesty\'s control. They are waiting only for King Bell\'s sanction and co-operation to petition the British Government to be included in the British Realm. They are getting tired of their attempts to govern themselves. Every dispute leads to war—and often to great loss of life." And after enumerating evils, atrocities, and intimidations, he concludes, "This state of affairs would be quite altered upon British occupation. Civilization would be at a premium then, and the people not afraid of mending their habits." The only real and efficient remedy for the paralyzing evils that prevail, is thus pointed out, in both cases, to be British government. This agrees with the opinions we have for a long time expressed. We see no other hope for those places; and, alas! in view of the prevailing policy in England, this is the same as saying, "There is no hope at all." We dissent altogether from that policy, Lord Derby and his Liverpool speech notwithstanding. It is a modern, sceptical, bastard, un-English policy, unworthy of a great Christian nation—a direct repudiation of the sacred obligations that God has imposed on it by its prosperity. It is, however, not the less an effectual bar at present to all action in the direction indicated from Old Calabar and the Cameroons. The delusion is strong among the governing class in Great Britain. If permanent, it will prove to be a fatal one. The hand never stands still upon the dial-plate of nations; from the moment it ceases to advance, it recedes. But the delusion must pass away ere long. New and increasing sources of national wealth must be discovered and utilized, if the stupendous, conventional, social edifice in the British Islands is to be supported. That we have a famine to deal with in India, and that this and similar catastrophes, which it is, alas! only too reasonable for us to expect, may impose on us great national sacrifices, is so far from being a convincing argument against further British extension and vigorous world-development action, that it weighs, to our mind, heavily in the opposite scale; heavily in favour of bold and confident progress, instead of retrogression, or even apathy. We have touched upon this subject before, when urging our views as regards the development of the resources of the Gambia and Niger rivers; and we shall avail ourselves of every opportunity of enforcing what we believe to be a truth of vital importance to Great Britain and her people. The West Coast of Africa, including those now non-progressing Oil Rivers, is a vast mine of national wealth for Great Britain, if she will only seriously direct her energies to its civilization and development. One intelligent European succeeded in penetrating, some years ago, to the interior of one of those oil rivers, and his inference from all that he saw was that, if that river were under European control, the existing wretched monopoly put an end to, and free and secure access to the interior permitted and afforded, the produce of the interior brought down for shipment would, within a very short time, be quadrupled—with a corresponding increase, of course, of those manufactured goods and other commodities which the natives would desire to obtain. At scarcely any, if any, of these oil ports is it an aboriginal people that now bars, as described, the passage to the interior. They are the descendants of interior tribes, who, when the foreign slave trade was at its height, pressed down to the coast: marauders, plunderers, kidnappers, in the interior; slave-traders at the sea side, with barracoons and slave depôts filled with the wretched human beings destined for the plantations on the other side the Atlantic. Forced to abandon their slave-trade practices, they have since been useful in the early stages of the work of transition to legitimate commerce. But this does not confer on them any right or title to prevent the light of civilization from penetrating to that interior, from which they aforetime drew their supplies of slaves, and now their oil. There are now in all these communities some men of a certain degree of education and intelligence—advantages which many of them use to their own dishonour and disgrace, instead of to their honour and repute. The dominant persons at Old Calabar are, we believe, among this class. We recommend to their consideration the certainty that, although the present policy of Great Britain will prevent their being immediately deprived of the power they so vilely and dishonestly use, they will certainly not be permitted much longer to outrage both the letter and spirit of those stipulations with Great Britain, under which they are at present allowed to exercise authority. It is the ruling desire of the people of Great Britain that the light of the glorious Gospel of Jesus Christ shall have free course among the African populations. It is only by respecting and lending themselves to the furtherance of those desires, that the now tolerated authorities at the Oil River ports can entertain\n117', 'last_edit_date': '1877-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1877#article-21', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.673, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'ENGLAND AND HER WEST AFRICAN COLONIES.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Turning to the question of the political administration of the Colonies at the present time, he enumerated the different systems of government prevailing in the various British Colonies in Africa, and said that the great benefits derived by the Colonies from their annexation to England, whose constitutional monarchy was the most stable system of representative government to be found in the whole world, were conspicuous and great. England had extended to her West African dependencies the privileges of British legitimate trade and commerce, which was a powerful vehicle for the advancement of civilisation.\n\nBringing forward the commercial advancement of the West African Colonies, he said the question had often been asked, "Do the Colonies pay?" He could answer with an emphatic affirmative. In 1837 the total external trade of England with all the Colonies was £28,341,471; it was now nearly £300,000,000, thus showing an increase of about ten times. The British shipping in connexion with the Colonies in 1837 was 3,677,975 tons; in 1885 it was 56,611,075 tons. The English Customs returns reckoned the exports to the Colonies in 1837 at £11,283,363; and this had since risen to £54,545,553. Her Majesty\'s Colonies, he said, furnished more than a quarter of the whole world\'s annual supply of gold. He then referred to the commercial geography of the British African Colonies, gave the value of their exports and imports, and reviewed the trade generally. The construction of a railway to the interior of Africa from Lagos was a recent proposition and a new feature in the history of the West African Colonies. It was obvious that Africa was, or would be, the only continent open for the future expansion of British manufacture; in such a case the interior would play an important part. He maintained, with eminent authorities on the subject, that by native agency alone, under foreign supervision necessarily, could tropical Africa be gradually and definitely developed on any permanent basis, and that the negro should be educated industrially and otherwise with the generous help of Europe and America. Whatever was accomplished by native agency, England certainly should carry the credit of effecting such accomplishment in the civilisation of Africa. It was beyond doubt that the English were acknowledged the best colonisers; and the marked consideration invariably shown by them to the people whom they undertook to govern, the extreme liberty and entire privileges of a British subject extended to every native, and the judicious caution characteristic of the policy of the British Government had altogether won for England this success and the preference to all other civilised nations. From the past and present history they might reasonably hope for the dawning of still better, brighter, and happier days upon the future of Africa.', 'last_edit_date': '1891-12-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1891#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.678, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'BRITISH ADMINISTRATION IN WEST AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'West Africa is one of the richest mineral regions on the planet, and England has been given an entrance to it for the purpose of spreading a civilisation and Christianity that will not do harm to the cause of the Gospel or bring disgrace on morality. The Mohammedan traders on the west coast of Sierra Leone, when asked where they get their precious metals and fine work, turn round and point to the north-east—Segoo, Bambara. Why have we not been in Bambara years ago? A light railway should have been run up to the north-east. The French are outstripping us along the line, and they deserve to; for St. Louis alone is an example of their superiority to us as colonisers. They are tapping all that rich region while we remain inert.\n\nWest Africa has, from interested motives, been represented as unhealthy for Europeans. This illusion is being rapidly dispelled by disinterested travellers. The Englishman, through unhealthy habits, may dig his own grave even in England, as so many thousands do annually. Besides, were London as innocent of sanitary arrangements as Freetown, it would soon become the white man\'s grave in grim reality. All that we require to do is to get rid of the drink, open out the country as honest people, and make room for our surplus population, from the nobleman\'s son down to the humblest artisan and labourer. There is fibre there for our manufacturers of Lancashire and Yorkshire; there is gold, silver, copper, coal, precious stones, ivory, india-rubber, nitrate, indigo, antimony, guano, palm oil, kola, ebony, mahogany, gum-copal, potash, ginger, gum, iron, farinaceous foods, dye woods, tanning material, spices, coffee, tobacco, cocoa, cotton, and other produce. When Great Britain set herself to the task of redeeming the great debt which she, above all nations, owed to Africa—for was not she the originator of the shameful Slave Trade?—she was prompted doubtless by the best of motives, but did not fully appreciate the difficulties of the task she then undertook. Landing in this English settlement I was', 'last_edit_date': '1891-03-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_03_1891#article-7', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.679, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African Times.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'If the character, in a geographical sense, of the burning questions of the hour be analysed, it will be found that Africa and African interests engage the greater part of Englishmen\'s thoughts at the present moment. The progress of the Khartoum Relief Expedition, the better government of Egypt, the high-handed action of the Boers in Zululand, the activity of German aggression on the West Coast, and the vast possibilities involved in the systematic colonisation of the Congo territory, represent only a few of the more urgent considerations now forcing themselves on the country\'s attention. Yet this enumeration, brief though it be, more than suffices to show the extent and importance of English interests in Africa. In view of the active ambition of other nations, these two points cannot be too frequently or too strongly insisted upon; for the physical peculiarities of the "Dark Continent" find their counterpart in its political features. Among the great divisions of the globe it occupies an absolutely unique position. Excepting the Valley of the Nile, Cape Colony and the immediately adjoining territories, together with little more than a fringe of coast settlements, Africa might, not long since, have been broadly and generally described as one vast "No Man\'s Land." But while this prospect has excited the envy, it has also stirred the emulation of other nations, and England apparently is not to be allowed to shape and wield the destinies of the "Dark Continent" either undisturbed or unopposed. hh: Christian missions in Africa involved significant contributions from local converts and African individuals, who actively shaped their religious experiences and influenced both colonial and local affairs.
result: Christian missions in Africa were significantly shaped by the contributions of local converts and African individuals, as evidenced by both the General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles. The textbook highlights the pivotal roles played by African converts, catechists, and ministers, particularly after 1914, with figures like Canon Apolo Kivebulaya and Bishop Samuel Ajayi Crowther leading missionary efforts and working beyond their ethnic groups. The emergence of separatist or independent churches, which integrated African beliefs and practices, further illustrates how Africans actively shaped their religious experiences. Mission-educated Africans became evangelists, teachers, and leaders, influencing both colonial and local affairs, while Afro-American missionaries and Afro-Christian churches underscored the active participation of Africans in the religious landscape. Similarly, The African Times articles emphasize the crucial role of native ministers, such as Mr. Bernasko, in facilitating missionary activities like Captain Burton's visit to Dahomey. The Wesleyan Missionary Society's reliance on native agents for evangelization, due to language and climate challenges faced by Europeans, highlights the importance of African involvement. The success of native converts as teachers and the efforts of leaders like the Right Rev. Samuel Adjai Crowther in the Niger Mission, including fundraising for church construction, demonstrate their significant influence in religious and colonial contexts. Together, these sources affirm the active involvement and impact of local converts and African individuals in shaping Christianity and influencing broader socio-political affairs in Africa.

It may seem odd at first sight that people drew ideological inspiration for their struggle against European conquerors from the very religion those conquerors imposed on them. [{'id': 465, 'article_title': 'LIBERIA.', 'full_section_title': 'LIBERIA.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1864#article-4', 'issue_date': '23_11_1864', 'content': 'No newspapers have reached us from this republic, and our information is altogether very meagre. We wish our friends there would give us more ample and regular information of the progress and prospects of Liberia. We have a most sincere desire to help her in her onward march to a large development of her undoubtedly rich resources. It has, therefore, given us great satisfaction to hear that there are now on the banks of the St. Paul's River alone 458 acres of land under sugar-cane cultivation, of which above 100 acres have been planted this year. The estimate of crop which has been sent to us from these plantations seems to be, however, very low; so low, that we think there must be some error, unless a larger portion of the cane than we are aware of is of too recent planting to give good crops this season. The produce is returned at 307 tons of sugar and 160 tons of molasses. The plantation of one of our correspondents alone has produced 100 tons. We should have been glad to see the cotton industry well established in Liberia; but as sugar planting has been preferred, and as both soil and climate are admirably adapted for the cane, we expect shortly to find Liberia among the great sugar-producing countries. Natal—the account of this year's crops of sugar in which we published last month—should stir the Liberians to emulation.

We are glad to see that merchant ships on the coast, and the passengers in mail steamers, are subscribing, though not very liberally, to that admirable institution, St. Mark's Hospital, at Cape Palmas.

Our friends of the Mendi Mission at the Sherboro, who have lately paid a visit to Cape Palmas, make the following satisfactory report. After commenting upon St. Mark's Hospital, the Asylum for the Blind, the Orphan Asylum, &c., all of which institutions have been founded by that indefatigable labourer in the cause of God and man, the Rev. Mr. Hoffman, they proceed as follows:—

"But the tide of improvement in other respects has not risen very rapidly. Operations best calculated to promote the interest of any country have been sadly neglected, until within the last two years. Men of means preferred trade to the cultivation of the soil. The major part of the people have struggled in a menial way, while regions of soil as fertile as any in the world continued under the bush. But such a state of things is changing. The farming interest is becoming general; leading men are taking hold of the matter with determination. The base idea that to dig the soil and turn out its wealth is degrading, is being displaced by its opposite, that to till the soil is the only way to independence.'}, {'id': 681, 'article_title': 'WEST COAST OF AFRICA', 'full_section_title': 'WEST COAST OF AFRICA', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1865#article-0', 'issue_date': '23_09_1865', 'content': 'Dear Sir,—In the newspapers lately received from England, I find that at a meeting of the Anthropological Society, held in April, Mr. Walker and Captain Burton spoke against the missionaries, and their labours in this country. I wish you to give publicity in your valuable paper to the following facts: Captain Burton, in his speech, said "that the Christian converts were the curse of Western Africa." Before leaving this coast, on his last visit, he wrote the following letter to the members of the Wesleyan Missionary Committee: "I cannot terminate my journey to Dahomey without expressing my gratitude to your missionary at Whydah, the Rev. Mr. Bernasko. That gentleman not only made my visit pleasant by his kindness and civility, but also enabled me, by his influence with the King, to contribute my hints in the cause of humanity and civilisation. Having heard that you entertain an idea of removing the Wesleyan missionary from Whydah, I would respectfully suggest to you the advisability of adopting a wholly different course, of strengthening rather than of abolishing it; and wholly unsolicited I have ventured to address to you these few lines." Let me say that Mr. Bernasko, about whom Captain Burton writes, is a native minister, and therefore a "Christian convert."

Mr. Walker, from his speech, appears to be also an enemy to the missions in Africa. Before he left Lagos he took the chair at the Annual Wesleyan Missionary Meeting held there, and spoke in the strongest language of the benefits derived from the labours of missionaries.

The above facts speak for themselves.—Yours faithfully,  
An Englishman.

---

Clean cotton was lately selling at only four-pence per pound in Abeokuta. We suppose, however, that the raising of the blockade by the Lagos authorities will have caused some advance in price.

The Stag, belonging to Thomas Brown and Co., of Bathurst, arrived at Liverpool on the 8th inst., with a full cargo of cotton from the River Gambia, being the first full cargo of cotton imported from that colony.

**A DISAGREEABLE POSITION FOR A COLONY.**—We hear a great deal about the home authorities considering that the colonies should mainly defend themselves in internal disturbances; if they were to add that in such a case they would grant a proportionate practical management of the coloured population, I have no doubt the colonists would much more readily turn out for drill en masse. At present, practically, the home authorities say, "We, though knowing next to nothing of your Kaffirs, will manage them as we like; but if we get you into a mess, you are the proper people to get yourselves out of it; and even then you must only do it in such a manner as we shall direct, which may be a very ineffective way, but that is no business of yours."—*Natal Mercury.*
**[SEPTEMBER 23, 1865.**

---

George, Esq., have been appointed members of the Legislative Council. The Rev. James Johnson was to leave Lagos in the beginning of August for England, on invitation from the Committee of the Church Missionary Society. We learn that Governor Moloney and Mr. Justice Smalman Smith have done good service in getting the interior matters settled without the assistance of busy-bodies who are fond of arrogating to themselves powers they do not possess; and these latter are quite sore now that several delegates have come to Lagos from the contending parties in the interior, and that matters are quietly adjusted without their influence being asked.'}]

[{'document_title': 'AFRICA AND THE JUBILEE FUND OF THE WESLEYAN MISSIONARY SOCIETY', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The Wesleyan Missionary Society have raised a large Jubilee Fund at Leeds, and other towns. We are glad to see that a prominent place is given to Africa and her children in the contemplated disposal of it. The following is from the monthly organ of the Society: "It was deeply felt by the Committee that the hope for the evangelization of Africa must mainly rest on the employment of a native agency. The difficulties of the African languages form a barrier to the free labour of English missionaries among the African nations, and the climate of large portions of that vast continent is very unfavourable to European health and life. At the same time, on every mission in Western and in Southern Africa there have been found native converts who have been deemed suitable to be employed as teachers among their countrymen. Some of these have been honoured of God with great success. It is desired that means may be provided for the training and employment of a much larger number of native African agents; and that at important centres, hereafter to be selected, schools or institutions should be formed for that purpose, to be commenced and sustained by an appropriation from the Jubilee Fund. In contemplation of the vastness of the field of labour in Africa it will be admitted that a large amount may with propriety be consecrated to this service.', 'last_edit_date': '1863-11-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1863#article-23', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.673, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Bishop of the Niger Territory', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The Right Rev. Samuel Adjai Crowther, D.D., missionary Bishop of the Niger Territory, has been staying at the Church Missionary House, in Salisbury Square, London. He has come over to England upon a special mission, namely, to raise funds for the building of a new church on the Niger. The Bishop, who is a venerable-looking gentleman, now in his eighty-first year, very quiet in manner, and with all the impressive actions which belong to the negro race, has had a life full of adventure which has been almost entirely devoted to the propagation of the Christian religion among his fellow-natives. While yet a child he was kidnapped from his tribe—the Yorubas—and sold at Lagos in 1822. He was, however, rescued by a British ship, taken to Sierra Leone, and educated there by the Church Missionary Society. He was baptised in 1825, and was afterwards employed as a teacher, and in 1843, having been ordained priest, he was sent to his own country, Yoruba, to assist in the conversion of his people. In 1857 he was appointed leader of the New Niger Mission, and on St. Peter's day 1864, he was consecrated at Canterbury Cathedral the first Bishop of the Niger. Since that date his whole energy has been devoted to the conversion of the heathen in those regions.

The other day a representative of the _Pall Mall Gazette_ had a few minutes' chat with the aged Bishop. "You want me to tell you something of my work in Africa?" said he, speaking with a sort of lisp and an accent, reminding one of a Russian speaking English. "Well, what can I tell you. We are progressing in a wonderful manner. The white traders, who are Christians, have quite abandoned work on Sunday, and instead come to worship at our church and chapels. More, they bring the natives down from the country to worship with us. Not Christian natives, you must understand, but heathens. The traders do this. They are not missionaries, but they help us in our missionary work. At one chapel 250 of these heathens come regularly and join in the service. I am over here on a special mission, come to collect money to build a new church, which we want very much."

It enables us to import those commodities for the production of which the climate and soil of foreign countries are best calculated, and to export in payment those articles for which our own situation is better adapted. It is virtually a mode of cheapening production, the commodities exported rising in value, and those imported decreasing in value, caused by the increase of demand in the one, and of supply in the other. At the same time, the manufacture of those commodities for which we have no particular facilities is decreased. Take cloth, for instance; the manufacture of cloth out here costs at least a fifth more than if imported. West Africa has great natural advantages for the cultivation of the palm tree; thus the manufacture of palm oil is carried on with great success. This commodity is enough not only to supply the wants of the people, but to satisfy the demands of England, Germany, and other European countries, which, owing to climate, are unsuited for the cultivation of the palm. Thus, from an economist's point of view, commercial enterprise of Europeans in Africa is good for three reasons. First, it enables us to profit by the inventions and discoveries of the Europeans, from whom we get steamers, canals, railways, and the minor advantages of art and science, and also a certain amount of refinement in dress and manners. Then, being dependent on each other for a large amount of comfort and enjoyment, it forms a powerful principle of union, and binds the society of nations together by the common and powerful ties of mutual interest and reciprocal obligation. And, lastly, by bringing us into competition with foreigners, the division of labour is carried to its farthest extent; it stimulates our industry, and forces routine to give way to invention. Commerce is the principal medium for the propagation of Christianity. In some West African countries, Europeans are at first only admitted for commercial purposes. hh: Religious leadership played a crucial role in the spiritual and communal life of West African communities during the colonial period, as evidenced by the significant anticipation and impact of the Bishop's arrival in Lagos.
result: The role of religious leadership in the spiritual and communal life of West African communities during the colonial period is underscored by observations from both the "General History of Africa" textbook and The African Times news articles. The textbook highlights the significant influence of religious figures such as James Johnson and William Wade Harris, who were instrumental in advocating for Nigerian nationalism, Ethiopianism, and the establishment of independent African churches like the United Native African Church and the Native Baptist Church. These movements reflect the broader religious and cultural dynamics, including the spread of Christianity and Islam and the integration of traditional and new religious practices. However, the textbook does not specifically mention the anticipation and impact of a Bishop's arrival in Lagos. In contrast, The African Times articles provide detailed accounts of the Bishop's arrival in Lagos, which was met with great joy and considered a significant event. The Bishop's activities, such as preaching to full congregations, conducting confirmations and ordinations, and opening new churches, highlight his influential role in the religious and communal life of the area. The establishment of the Lagos Native Pastorate Church and the Bishop's involvement in its formation further underscore the importance of religious leadership. Together, these sources illustrate the central role of religious leadership in shaping the spiritual and communal life of West African communities during the colonial period, with the Bishop's arrival in Lagos serving as a poignant example of this influence.

Mrs. Drinau is one of the very few ladies who have visited Cape Coast who have shown the natives what good, real good, a real Christian lady can accomplish; and now she has set to work to train our choir, who are making great progress under her tuition, she herself playing the harmonium in our pretty little church. I am now more and more impressed with the belief that good Mrs. Mosely will find valuable assistance here in many ways for her great work.—Yours truly,

A Churchman.'}, {'id': 2134, 'article_title': 'Confirmations at Lagos by the Bishop of Sierra Leone', 'full_section_title': 'Confirmations at Lagos by the Bishop of Sierra Leone', 'last_edit_date': '12-07-1871', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_01_1872#article-14', 'issue_date': '23_01_1872', 'content': "Sir,—We are glad to inform you that the Lord Bishop of this diocese arrived here safely with Mrs. Cheetham on the 17th November, and was well received by the clergy, churchwardens, and the community at large. It is a cause of great joy to us, after the lapse of nearly seven years, to see a bishop of this diocese come down to Lagos. We pray that his life and that of his lady may be long spared, and that their health may permit them to labour many years in Africa.

His lordship preached at Christ Church on Sunday, the 19th November, to a full congregation, and on St. Andrew's Day, Nov. 30, he had confirmation, when 225 persons were confirmed in Christ Church. On Advent Sunday, the 3rd inst., he had ordination, when four native candidates were admitted to deacon's orders, and the Rev. H. Townsend preached the ordination sermon. On Tuesday, the 5th inst., he confirmed 166 persons in St. Paul's Church; and this day his lordship opened a new church at Iddo Island, in the vicinity of Lagos, and held a confirmation in the church at Iota Metta, on the mainland to the northern district of this settlement. On Thursday next, the 14th inst., his lordship will (D.V.) held confirmation in the church at Badagry. The Bishop was to have presided at the anniversary meeting of the Local Branch of the British and Foreign Bible Society, in the Wesleyan Chapel, Tinubu-square, on Monday, the 27th November; but, owing to his indisposition, our worthy friend, the Hon. A. H. Porter took the chair. Hence you see the arrival of the Bishop has enlivened our community, and we trust that the season has been a great blessing to us. The Bishop and lady will return for Sierra Leone in January.

With compliments of the approaching season, I remain, yours truly,  
OLOGUNDUDU."}]

Finally, in March last, during the visit of the Lord Bishop of the diocese from Sierra Leone, acting in accordance with the instructions of the C.M.S., a resolution was proposed and carried at a meeting composed of clerical and lay members, that the time had come for the establishment of the Native Pastorate in Lagos. The first church taken up is "the Holy Trinity Church, Ebute Ero." The deed was drawn up, and after approval was signed by the Lord Bishop. The first native pastor in this infant Church is the Rev. W. Morgan. On Monday, the 5th inst., sermons were preached in the morning at Christ Church, by the Rev. J. A. Maser, local Secretary of the C.M.S., in English, and in the evening at the Breadfruit Church, St. Paul's, by the Right Rev. Bishop Crowther, in Yoruba. A public meeting was held on Tuesday evening, in the Breadfruit Church, St. Paul's. The chair was taken at seven o'clock by his Excellency J. D. A. Dumaresq, the Administrator. After a hymn was sung, the Rev. J. A. Maser read a portion of the Scriptures. Rev. W. Morgan offered prayer. After an introductory speech by the Administrator, Rev. T. B. Macauley read the report, and Rev. James Johnson read the amount of contributions received. The following resolutions were then proposed and carried:—

J. S. Hill, who has been designated as the successor of the late Bishop Crowther as Bishop of the Niger, and who, though not at present consecrated, has gone out as Commissary of the Archbishop of Canterbury, who is guardian of the See during its vacancy, the following address was presented to him on behalf of the members of the Lagos Native Church:—

Lagos, December 7, 1892.

Rev. and Dear Sir,—We, the undersigned, Native Ministers and Members of the Lagos Native Church which we represent, beg very respectfully to express to you and through you to his Grace the Archbishop of Canterbury, whose Commissary you are, our grateful appreciation of his kind consideration for the West African Churches generally in sending you out, in the first instance, to make an inquiry into certain matters affecting the Niger Diocese, with a view to an Episcopal appointment in succession to that of our beloved friend, brother and senior, the late Bishop Crowther, and of the desire of the Church Missionary Society, which you in some measure also represent to us, for the restoration of harmony and mutual understanding between it and the Niger Delta Church and the other West African Churches; also, in regard to certain grave occurrences which have transpired in the Niger Mission. We further respectfully beg, on behalf of ourselves and the Lagos Church, to tender you our sincere and hearty thanks for having undertaken this mission of inquiry and peace, and for the opportunity you have afforded us through a Conference for a free discussion and full consideration with you of some of the important questions which have sprung up in connexion with the Niger and the other African Churches, and for your very important contribution to the peaceful, friendly and helpful character of the Conference; and we hope your mission will materially help to bring about the end desired, and prove a gain to West African Christianity.', 'last_edit_date': '1892-12-07', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1893#article-1', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.686, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'LAGOS, ABEOKITA, AND PORTO NOVO.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'An American Missionary, writing to the New York _Monitor_, gives the following account of Lagos, Abeokuta, and Porto Novo:

Lagos being the principal seaport of a large territory of palm trees, makes it one of the most important cities on the West Coast. The Island Lagos is a British colony, with a population of 60,000. About 5,000 are nominally Christians, 10,000 Mahomedans, and 45,000 Pagan or heathen. Several large societies are working here on the island—viz., the Wesleyans and Church Mission Societies of England, the Catholics of France, and the Southern Baptist, U.S.A. They have good schools and church buildings, and are labouring hard for the improvement of the people.', 'last_edit_date': '1879-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1879#article-18', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.683, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Death of the Rev. Thos. Babington Macaulay, Principal of the Church Missionary Society’s Grammar School at Lagos.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We have received a notice of the lamented decease of the Rev. T. B. Macaulay, which characterizes this sad event as the “most appalling, panic-striking, universal calamity which has befallen the whole West African community.” The writer does not give any information on this point, but we believe Mr. Macaulay died a victim to the small-pox epidemic which has been raging so fearfully at Lagos. Although we cannot insert the observations of our correspondent, we are nevertheless deeply sensible of the loss that West Africa has sustained by Mr. Macaulay’s death. Many of the pupils taught by him are pursuing an honourable career, and the grief at his loss will no doubt be extensively felt.

Mr. Macaulay died, after ten days’ illness, on (if we read aright) the 17th January; and his remains were interred in the Public Cemetery at Lagos, the funeral service being conducted by the Right Rev. S. A. Crowther, D.D., Bishop of the Niger Territory.

Our correspondent closes with a prayer in which we most heartily unite: “May God undertake to comfort the bereaved friends and family, the aged widow mother, the widow of the deceased, and the orphans.”—Ed. A.T.', 'last_edit_date': '1878-04-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1878#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.68, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Change of "Administrator" at Lagos', 'section_title': '', 'content': "British colonies and settlements on the West Coast were in duty bound to contribute by influence and example to the spread of Christian influences and observances. That they have heretofore too generally done the very reverse of this is unhappily notorious. It would therefore have been so easy for the new Administrator to fall into the old groove, and then return to England and testify to the uselessness of missionary exertion as evidenced by the lax morality of many of that rising community of educated natives who have been instructed in the various mission schools—and this, as is usual in such cases, without one word of condemnation for British delinquents, whose conduct might be equally held to prove the worthlessness of religious education in England, and by whose pernicious example so much that is evil has been inculcated and encouraged. Without any disrespect or hostility to Captain Glover, we may therefore express our regret at the removal of Rear-Admiral Patey from Lagos, and the return of Captain Glover as Administrator to that colony. But as the Colonial-office in its supreme wisdom has thus appointed, we can only express the hope that in the important particular to which we have above alluded Captain Glover will follow in the steps of his immediate predecessor. As representing a Christian sovereign and a Christian country, we hope that he too will show at least an official regard to Christian institutions, which are not intended to be merely local, but universal. And there are other points on which we think it necessary strongly to insist. The first and foremost, because in it are involved many others, is that his policy should now be a policy of peace and goodwill, such as will, by the maintenance of pacific relations with all around, tend to the development and increase of the commerce of Lagos. It is thus only that such a revenue can be obtained as Lagos requires for the prosecution of those sanitary and other works of civilization, in which we must do him the justice to say he was not lax when previously in authority as Acting Governor. But to effect this it is not alone necessary to obtain a revenue. There ought also to be a strict economy in every department, the abolition of all offices not indispensable to the public service, and the filling of all offices, as far as possible, with educated Africans. It is only by the latter that the Africans can be educated for self-government, as recommended by the Committee of the House of Commons of 1864; and it is only by economising the revenue in the matter of official salaries, of police (which has been on far too large and costly a scale), and of general unproductive expenditure, that money can be found for making Lagos a place in which Europeans may reside with comparative safety to health, for giving her the nucleus of those institutions which ought everywhere to mark the presence of Christian civilised rule, and for making the island a pattern and example to the natives of the interior who will be drawn thither by an increasing trade. We like to praise, and we therefore hope to have much to praise Captain Glover for in the exercise of his power as Her Majesty's Administrator at Lagos.", 'last_edit_date': '1866-11-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1866#article-25', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.674, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE NATIVE CHURCH OF SIERRA LEONE', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The Revs. D. G. Williams and N. H. Boston, two native clergy, are now in England, bearing with them the following statement of the needs of the Church upon the West Coast, from the Bishop of Sierra Leone:

"... I send with them a clear statement of our purpose, and especially of those circumstances which are making us feel the need of sympathy, help, and encouragement from our brethren in the Mother Church. In venturing to trouble you with a few facts, I am acting as the spokesman of all those principal Church members who assembled at Kissy Road Church, on June 2, to bid our brethren God speed; and I trust the following statement may meet the eye of many friends of Africa.

(1.) This is the scene of the earliest work of the Church Missionary Society. It was led up to by striking providences. It has been costly in human life as well as in money. Not less than half a million, I believe, has been spent here. The outward and visible result is a compact Native Church of some fifteen parishes, not including the cathedral, with a native pastor, parsonage, church and school in each parish.

(2.) This Church, though mainly self-supporting, is still receiving £300 per annum from the C.M.S., which is now being withdrawn at the rate of £50 per annum. We raised last year, for instance, for the Pastorate, _amongst ourselves_, £1,169 18s. 3d class pence alone producing £937 14s. 11d. This is about the average.

(3.) We are a missionary Church. The C.M.S. handed over its missions to the Native Church in 1875. Our Society is called the Sierra Leone Church Missionary Society. We have two missions in the Bullom and in the Quiah country. We have two ordained missionaries with catechists under them. They cost us about £400 per annum. These missions are not making much progress; we scarcely maintain the _status quo_. We can only be said to affirm the principle of the thing. All this thickly populated region, from the far interior to our very border, is practically unevangelized.

(4.) Sierra Leone is only important, financially, as a depot for trade. The Peninsula, though mountainous and fair-looking, is unproductive. A good understanding with the tribes in the interior is all that is wanted to make the Colony prosperous. We have a fine harbour, and are accessible to England, but the place by itself will neither support a Church nor even a Government. And thus I come to the ground of our plea for sympathy and help. Our importance as a Church is that we may be a depot for the interior and around. Heathen and Mahomedans trade with us, settle amongst us, and crowd our streets every day. Nothing is being done for them. Their influence on us is not for good. We are engaged in hand-to-hand intercourse, but not hand-to-hand conflict with their superstitions and sins. The result is enfeebling. We are awakening to feel our need of more spiritual power. We are planning for a general mission next dry season, but we desire to make known other needs only second in importance.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-07-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_07_1885#article-23', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.674, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Bishop of Sierra Leone on the Education of the West African', 'section_title': '', 'content': "The Christianity which Bishop Ingham longs to propagate in the Black Continent is a system of conduct; it must manifest itself in practical utilities, and not in barren propositions. But if this be so, what are we to say to the Bishop's straightforward, melancholy statement that “the country around Sierra Leone, and even the greater part of the Colony itself, is in just as wild and undeveloped a state as it was in 1787?” Clarkson and his associates began their work more than 100 years ago, in the hope of Christianising the continent; but the Christianisation of the little peninsula of Sierra Leone still remains sadly incomplete.", 'last_edit_date': '1894-07-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_07_1894#article-9', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.698, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'EDUCATION ON THE WEST COAST OF AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'This meeting has created a great sensation in Lagos. All the young folks have determined to get a degree. In that meeting there were ministers of the Church, Wesleyans, and Baptists present, Europeans and natives, with the most intelligent of the community, including our native members of the Roman Catholic Church. The meeting was a great success. Surely, this must be gratifying news to Christian friends of Africa. Mr. Davies returned by mail to Sierra Leone on the 16th inst., much pleased with his reception at Lagos.—Your obedient servant,

PROGRESS.', 'last_edit_date': '1880-01-20', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_03_1880#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.687, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'EDUCATION IN WEST AFRICA', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'When writing last month on the all-important subject of the future spread of Christian civilization in West Africa, we pointed out that educated natives, more or less under the influence of Christian faith, more or less imbued with Christian principles, more or less governed by Christian precepts, are and will be indispensable as a vanguard of the great army of civilization that must be projected upon the ignorant barbarism of heathen Africa whenever the means for such projection shall be arranged. We go further than this, and equally maintain that not only the vanguard of the army of civilization must necessarily consist of educated Africans, but that the army itself must be chiefly composed of them. With this conviction rooted in our mind, the question of education in West Africa has for many years past greatly occupied our attention. The end in view being so great, and of so vast importance primarily to Africa, and secondarily to the whole civilized world, it is natural we should have asked ourself whether the means of education at present employed are adequate for the purpose; and if not, how and by whom those means are to be made so. We have already adverted to the unselfish efforts of the religious societies of Great Britain (and in the case of Liberia, of those of the United States of America) in diffusing among the natives the great blessing of education. The efforts of the Missionary Societies, and more especially of the Church Missionary Society, have been unremitting and gradually increasing in scope and efficiency, until they would seem at last to have culminated in the affiliation of their Fomah Bay College at Sierra Leone to the University of Durham, whereby degrees may be obtained by Africans who have never left their native land. By these efforts of Missionary Societies, the Church of England and the Wesleyan Methodist, all who can boast of any degree of education in West Africa have been rescued from heathen ignorance, and prepared more or less, for civilized usefulness. It was, perhaps, well and unavoidable, though we are far from saying or thinking that it was so, that so all-important a work, if Africa is ever to be rescued from heathen degradation, should have been hitherto left in the hands of the Missionary Societies. But that it ought any longer to be so left, we most emphatically deny. Under those noble efforts of the Missionary Societies, combined with constantly increasing facilities for commerce which steam navigation has supplied, the condition of the British settlements has undergone so great a change, that a continued dependence on missionary effort for the education of the people will, if persisted in, be a gross injustice and disgrace on the part of the British Government. This is so patent that we feel convinced it is only necessary the subject should be urged upon their attention to induce such action on their part as shall wipe away the reproach that now justly attaches to them, and relieve the Missionary Societies from a charge to which their funds, so urgently required for the propagation of Christian truth in other localities in the great heathen world, ought not to be any longer subject. Education ought to be now organized and diffused in and from the British settlements by and at the charge of the local revenues. The inadequacy of means, which as regards the Gold Coast, for instance, might have been pleaded some ten or twelve years ago, when the public revenue there did not exceed annually the sum of seven or eight thousand pounds, can no longer be urged now that the revenue has attained the comparatively magnificent amount of one hundred thousand pounds a year. A similar comparative increase has been experienced at Lagos; and if the revenues of Sierra Leone and the Gambia have not advanced in the same ratio, they are still sufficient, if properly administered, to meet the great and urgent want of public education, under the organization and auspices of the State. A State education is what we now claim for West Africa, and in especial for the Gold Coast and Lagos. A systematic and adequate commencement of it ought not to be any longer delayed. A Liberal Government in Great Britain cannot surely any longer deny to the people of West Africa that of which they have been such earnest promoters, both individually and collectively, at home. It can scarcely be necessary to remind the Earl of Kimberley that, as Crown Colonies, those settlements are altogether dependent upon an initiative from Downing-street; that themselves, the people, even if they felt the need, can do nothing; that the expenditure of the public revenue is entirely at the command of the Secretary of State for the Colonies; and that it now rests with him either to aid in or retard the Christian civilization of West Africa, which cannot progress without a more general diffusion of education than can or ought to be expected from the Missionary Societies of Great Britain. While, however, we are prepared to maintain that it is now the duty of Government to undertake the work of the education of the people, both elementary and higher, in all the West African settlements, we shall confine ourselves more especially at this time to the claims and needs of the Gold Coast and Lagos. The influence that may be diffused from these British settlements in the great work of the civilization of Africa would be immense, and justly entitles them to our especial consideration as regards public education in West Africa. It is from Lagos that the work of civilization must proceed to the moral conquest of the whole of those extensive territories that are bounded by the River Niger, and of that blood-stained kingdom of Dahomey, whose sanguinary customs continue, though of late but little spoken of, to outrage humanity, and exhibit the worst features of ignorant heathen barbarism. In considering the question of State education in Lagos, it is incumbent on the British Government to take into consideration that the public revenue of that portion of the Gold Coast Colony is derived entirely from traffic in the produce of those interior countries; that the spread of civilization increases production; and that therefore, while on the one hand it is imperatively their duty, it is not less their interest, as rulers of this Crown settlement, to devote a portion of that revenue to constitute Lagos a focus of light from Britain, to be diffused throughout the Egba and Yoruba countries, and the territories of their unquiet neighbour, Dahomey. The presence of Great Britain on the coasts of these countries of West Africa, after her own renunciation and denunciation of the infamous and horrible foreign slave-trade, was justified by her presence there being absolutely necessary for securing the final annihilation of that traffic, and remedying in some degree, by the security she gave and the repression she exercised, the fearful results that had been produced there by it, and the outrages on humanity perpetrated at the behests of sanguinary superstitions, which had been made through successive ages its active agents and accomplices. Under her ægis a new condition of things has gradually arisen; and although—such is the tenacity of evil—her presence could not even yet be dispensed with as regards the repression of slave-trading propensities, this repression ought now to be regarded as a secondary, and the spread of civilization the primary, justification of her continued rule. Those who have known this journal during the past twenty years cannot need to be reminded that we have ever laid it down as an axiom that a basis of British power on the Coast is indispensable to the success of missionary enterprise and the progress of civilization in Africa. The natives have become so debased by superstition during ages upon ages of heathen darkness, that they are incapable of believing in anything that does not come to them accompanied by evidences of power. They have such evidence at Lagos; they have it within the mainland territories of the Gold Coast Colony. ORD, THE COMMISSIONER APPOINTED TO INQUIRE INTO THE CONDITION OF THE BRITISH SETTLEMENTS ON THE WEST COAST OF AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The administration of justice is undertaken by a chief magistrate, a police magistrate, and the two civil commandants of Badagry and Palma, an establishment which appears sufficient for the duties which at present devolve upon it; eventually, however, as the inhabitants, of whom the number on the island is variously estimated between 40,000 and 80,000, and is probably nearer the larger than the smaller number, learn to avail themselves of the cheap and ready justice which our courts dispense, it may be expected that some additional will require to be made to the judicial staff.

It has been stated that the protection of the settlements has rendered expedient the establishment of a local armed force, raised from the natives of Houssa, large numbers of whom are found in Lagos, where they have, in most instances, been brought over as slaves. These people have a strong antipathy to their former masters, with a considerable aptitude for military duties; 100 of them have accordingly been organized as an armed police, who not only share in all the duties of the garrison, but also perform many others which the custom of the service prevents soldiers from being employed upon, and which are absolutely required in a new settlement in the position of Lagos; for example, when summonses from the court have to be executed by the ordinary civil police in localities where resistance may be apprehended, or when prisoners have to be brought through similar places, or when it is necessary to send messengers through disturbed districts, these men are found capable of executing such services with great courage and fidelity; whilst, when not so employed, they perform all the duties of soldiers, mounting guard over stores, magazines, buildings, &c., and are ready to turn out at once, on the order of the Governor, for the suppression of any disturbance or commotion.

It has been already stated that, in the contemplated reduction of the force on the West Coast of Africa, the two companies of black troops who form the garrison of Lagos are intended to be withdrawn; there being no proper barracks for officers or men, they have suffered considerably in their health, and as the cost for providing the necessary accommodation for them is estimated at 20,000l., it is considered better, as it will be more economical, to remove them at once, and to entrust the entire protection of the settlements to the Houssas, whose numbers will be somewhat augmented for the purpose.

There is as yet no Government ecclesiastical establishment, but the Church Missionary Society maintains three churches in Lagos and one in Badagry; the Wesleyans also support a church in Lagos.', 'last_edit_date': '1865-06-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_06_1865#article-20', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.674, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'CHURCH TOWER AND CLOCK IN LAGOS.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Influence to be exercised by it, that must produce incalculable blessings throughout those wide-spread territories, for the abundant production of which this once dark seat of a hideous slave trade, offers by its now well-filled port a ready and advantageous outlet. It is only ten years since this interesting little island was under native rule, and a sort of British protection, which had been afforded with the object of entirely suppressing the slave trade that was still a devastating agent in neighbouring countries. It was found, however, to be impossible to prevent this altogether, while the island should continue under native rule; some little slave trade was still secretly carried on with the native mainland; and as the actual ruler of the country was only so by reason of the efficacious protection afforded by a resident British agent, with British ships of war within call, it was wisely and humanely determined by the British Government, in which the power and influence of Lord Palmerston were then supreme, that the native King should retire upon a pension, and the settlement be made a British one. We were an ardent promoter of this change, and incurred great odium in consequence, among merchants who, under British protection, there carried on a successful trade without payment of the duties exacted where British authorities held sway; and among educated African traders, who but in too many cases abandoned in Lagos those restraints which Christian civilisation imposed on them in Sierra Leone. Lagos was then a filthy, pestiferous place, peculiarly fatal to Europeans. Ten years, only ten years, and what a change has been accomplished! At no other place in Africa has civilising progress been so rapid, or shown such irrepressible energy. Mistakes were made in the early days of British rule, which led for a time to an entire alienation of the powerful Egba nations on the mainland; eventuating in hostilities that for some time paralysed trade, and left bitter seeds of distrust in the native mind in Abeokuta and elsewhere. By a wiser policy, however, during the last four or five years, Administrator Glover has done much to redeem the past in that respect; abstaining from everything that could give rise to further distrust or suspicion. We are sorry sometimes to think that he never can obtain the confidence and goodwill of the Egba people; and that, in consequence, many works that would shed additional lustre upon his name, can never be effected by him. And here we think it well to take advantage of this opportunity to impress upon him the necessity, in the interests of Lagos, of not incautiously recommencing efforts such as for opening communication with Ibadan, &c., they may arouse anew the old hostile feelings, and that can only serve to retard the realisation of those useful objects which he no doubt has in view, but which we are persuaded the interior natives never can be brought to assent to and co-operate in, until Lagos shall possess an elected Legislative Council. When this right shall be accorded to her, the presence and influence of those educated African merchants and traders, civilised and Christian, which Lagos already has in no small number among her citizens, may and will enable the then Government of Lagos to overcome all suspicion and animosity, and to show Egbas, Ijebus, Ijeshas, and all concerned, that Lagos desires the introduction of such and such works among them, not from motives of ambition or lust of dominion, but for the mutual and reciprocal advancement of Lagos and the interior. That elected Legislative Council cannot be long denied to Lagos. Her progress is too rapid to permit of this. Her revenues, from duties on imports, are now, we believe, between 40,000l. and 50,000l. a-year. They will, no doubt, yearly increase. She has well-laid-out streets, presenting a striking contrast to the former agglomeration of the vilest class of African huts. Those streets are lighted. Sanitary improvements have made her a healthy place of residence, even for Europeans, if they will abstain from the indulgence of those destructive propensities which may be justly said to have dug by far the greater number of British graves along the West Coast. And having churches and chapels, which have been for the most part built by funds raised in Lagos itself, she is now making an effort for a church tower, with its public clock. We admire this public spirit among her educated African traders; and this particular manifestation of it has our warmest sympathy. We do not offer pecuniary aid; nor do we ask any one in England, unless he be a Lagos man absent for a time from his country, to give any aid. We are jealous for the reputation of Lagos. She is able now to do such works for her embellishment and convenience with her own money, and she will do it; and if the list of contributors be furnished to us when the necessary sum shall be all subscribed, we will immortalise them in our columns. Meanwhile we wish them heartily Godspeed; and we desire that those sincere friends of Africa who do exist in England, should take comfort in seeing what God has already wrought by the civilising and Christianising agencies of Great Britain, in a place where but a few years since the waters were daily defiled by the poor murdered victims of the brutal and abominable slave trade.', 'last_edit_date': '1871-09-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1871#article-14', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.679, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE AFRICAN IN THE WEST INDIES', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The Bishop made a good voyage to Jamaica, and arrived at Kingston on July 5. "The Bishop of Jamaica and quite a bodyguard of clergy were waiting for the gangway to be placed, and were soon on board to give us a hearty welcome. The moment we saw the Bishop in his own diocese we were conscious of his personality, and somehow we felt we were going to be well arranged for. And we were not disappointed. One of Bishop Ingham's first engagements was at the Diocesan Deaconess Home, and here are his impressions: 'There among the English sisters we saw the coloured nurses taking their part naturally and brightly, not only in the evening's entertainment, but in all the daily routine of work. Having been called upon to speak to the splendid gathering of men and women of all shades of colour convened under the auspices of these good deaconesses, it was pleasant to tell how we in Africa, in smaller and less developed ways, were doing much the same thing for the same great cause. But we have to be honest with ourselves and candidly admit that, for grace and refinement, for elocution and general freedom of manner, we could not produce in our Sierra Leone Temperance gatherings what we saw amongst the coloured people on this occasion.'"

Of the educational advantages of Jamaica the Bishop has much to say; particularly was he impressed by the Mico Training College for Schoolmasters: "The Bishop of Jamaica enabled us to inspect the new buildings, and also to meet the directors. At this meeting a letter from the London trustees was read, in which the Bishop of Sierra Leone's visit was referred to, and definite proposals were made in the way of an important new departure. Important resolutions were passed undertaking to carry out the ideas of trustees in London, and so, on requisition being made either by the Bishop of Sierra Leone or the Church Missionary Society, the Mico college is prepared at its own expense, to train, say, four men annually for educational work in Western Africa. We cannot adequately express our sense of the great importance of this definite stage now reached in our inquiry; and we say without fear of contradiction to those who have it in their power to use African teachers in West Africa, that they may confidently trust the directors, the staff, and the excellent influences, both spiritual and moral, brought to bear upon the students of this excellent College. There was not an African schoolmaster of any standing or pretensions whom we met in Jamaica who was not a Mico Alumnus: one has just been singled out by the Governor and placed upon the Board of Education."

The Bishop had a sort of Farewell Meeting with the diocesan clergy, at which he gave an address on the African situation.', 'last_edit_date': '1895-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1895#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.692, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The People of Lagos upon European Influence upon the West Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"Looking at the question from an economist's point of view, commercial intercourse with foreigners enriches our country. hh: The crowning of the first Christian king in Cape Coast signified a major shift in local power dynamics and cultural transformation, reflecting the broader influence of Western religious and cultural values in Africa during the colonial period.
result: The claim that the crowning of the first Christian king in Cape Coast signified a major shift in local power dynamics and cultural transformation is supported by observations from both the "General History of Africa" textbook and The African Times news articles, albeit with differing emphases. The textbook provides a broader context of the influence of Christianity and Western cultural values in Africa during the colonial period, highlighting the introduction of Christianity, its impact on traditional beliefs, the spread of Western education, and the emergence of a Westernized African elite. However, it does not specifically mention the crowning of a Christian king in Cape Coast, indicating a gap in addressing this particular historical event. In contrast, The African Times articles offer detailed accounts of the crowning of King Haggerty II, a Christian and educated leader, as a pivotal moment in local power dynamics and cultural transformation. The articles emphasize the king's departure from traditional practices, such as human sacrifices, and his commitment to Christianity, marking a significant cultural shift on the Gold Coast. They also highlight the broader missionary efforts and European influence in promoting Christianity and civilization, aligning with the theme of Western cultural impact. However, the articles also reveal tensions in power dynamics, such as disputes with the British Governor, illustrating the complexities of reconciling traditional and colonial authorities. Together, these sources provide a nuanced understanding of the cultural and power shifts associated with the crowning of a Christian king, reflecting both the broader influence of Western values and the specific challenges faced in this historical context.
